details: Prop. D would amend the city charter to limit the city to 65 commissions, which are civilian oversight or advisory bodies for city departments. The city currently has around 130 commissions. Prop. D would also give the mayor more power to appoint commissioners and to hire and fire department heads.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. E: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.

sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Philip Halperin
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Philip Halperin
committee_name: Great Schools For All Sf Kids - Yes On Prop A
details: Prop. A would authorize the San Francisco Unified School District to borrow up to $790 million to be repaid through property taxes. The money could be used for health and safety upgrades, such as heating and plumbing, and technology infrastructure.
title: School improvement bond
sponsor: San Francisco Board of Education
required: Requires 55% affirmative votes.
proponents: SF Parent Action, SF Building and Construction Trades Council
opponents: Libertarian Party of San Francisco, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Philip Weiss
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.
title: Ride-hailing vehicle tax
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures gathered by over 100 volunteers
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. M: It must receive more votes than Prop. M to go into effect.

opponents: Uber, Lyft, GrowSF, TogetherSF Action, SF Chamber of Commerce, California Nightlife Association

name: Robert Fisher
committee_name: Healthy, Vibrant Sf, Yes On B
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Robin Pam
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Ronald Conway
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.
title: Business tax reform
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.
proponents: San Francisco Chamber of Commerce; Mayor London Breed; Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Rafael Mandelman, Catherine Stefani, Ahsha Safaí, Myrna Melgar and Connie Chan
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Ronald Conway
committee_name: Yes On F, San Franciscans For A Full Police Staffing
details: Prop. F would create a deferred retirement program for the police department. This would allow some officers, sergeants and inspectors to delay their retirement to do neighborhood patrols or investigative work. The measure would also change how the department reports staffing levels.
title: Police staffing
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar, Aaron Peskin, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: San Francisco Police Officers Association, Ripple executive chairman Chris Larsen, San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, Police Chief William Scott, Mayor London Breed

name: San Francisco Communities Against Displacement
committee_name: Yes On G, The Affordable Housing Opportunity Fund
candidate_or_measure: Funding Rental Subsidies For Affordable Housing Developments Serving Low Income Seniors, Families, And Persons With Disabilities
details: Prop. G is a charter amendment creating an affordable housing fund to subsidize some extremely low-income rentals. The city would be required to allocate at least $8.25 million a year to that fund and the mayor’s office of housing and community development would disburse that money to the owners of certain affordable housing complexes.
title: Rental subsidies
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, San Francisco Tenants Union, Mercy Housing, Mission Economic Development Agency, Affordable Housing Alliance, Latino Task Force
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso, TogetherSF Action

name: San Francisco Deputy Sheriffs Pac
committee_name: Support Our First Responders Now! Yes On N
candidate_or_measure: First Responder Student Loan And Training Reimbursement Fund
details: Prop. N would create a fund to repay first responders’ student loans. This would affect workers including sworn police officers, dispatchers, registered nurses and firefighters who would get up to $25,000 of their training costs reimbursed.
description: First responder student loan and training reimbursement fund
title: First responder student loan
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Dean Preston, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Service Employees International Union Local 1021, San Francisco Police Officers Association, San Francisco Deputy Sheriffs’ Association, Firefighters Local 798
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: San Francisco Electrical Contractors Association Inc.
committee_name: Mayor Mark Farrell For Yes On Prop D
details: Prop. D would amend the city charter to limit the city to 65 commissions, which are civilian oversight or advisory bodies for city departments. The city currently has around 130 commissions. Prop. D would also give the mayor more power to appoint commissioners and to hire and fire department heads.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. E: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.
proponents: TogetherSF Action, Michael Moritz, Mark Farrell, Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, billionaire hedge fund investor William Oberndorf
opponents: Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, ACLU of Northern California, Harvey Milk LGBT Democratic Club, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council

committee_name: Real Reform, Yes On C, No On D, Yes On E, A Coalition Of Small Businesses, Neighbors And Aaron Peskin
details: Prop. C would create an inspector general for San Francisco to investigate claims of fraud, waste and abuse. The inspector would have the power of subpoena and the power to issue search warrants.
title: Inspector general
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.

name: San Francisco Laborer'S Local 261 Pac
committee_name: Real Reform, Yes On C, No On D, Yes On E, A Coalition Of Small Businesses, Neighbors And Aaron Peskin
details: Prop. E would require the budget and legislative analyst to report on the fiscal impact of the city’s 130 commissions, and it would create a task force to determine how to change, eliminate or consolidate these commissions. It does not give more power to the mayor or the police chief.

name: Sanae Rosen
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.

opponents: Uber, Lyft, GrowSF, TogetherSF Action, SF Chamber of Commerce, California Nightlife Association

details: Prop. K would permanently close part of the Great Highway (between Lincoln and Sloat) to cars, in preparation for turning it into a park.
description: Close the Great Highway to cars
title: Close the Great Highway
sponsor: Supervisors Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar and Dean Preston
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: State Sen. Scott Wiener, Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi, Outer Sunset Neighbors, SF Surfers for Ocean Beach Park, Yelp CEO Jeremy Stoppelman, Sierra Club, Y Combinator pPartner Emmett Shear, SPUR, San Francisco Parks Alliance

name: Sara Flynn
committee_name: San Franciscans For Responsible Housing, No On Proposition B, Sponsored By Rental Housing Providers
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Sara Miles
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.
title: Ride-hailing vehicle tax
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures gathered by over 100 volunteers
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. M: It must receive more votes than Prop. M to go into effect.

title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action

name: Service Employees International Union Local 1021 Issues Pac
committee_name: Improve Emergency Responses Times - Yes On I
candidate_or_measure: Retirement Benefits For Nurses And 911 Operators
details: Prop. I would allow some registered nurses who are typically exempt from pension benefits to buy back up to three years of pension credits. It would also move 911 dispatchers from their current pension plan to a higher-paying one.
title: Retirement benefits for nurses
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Service Employees International Union Local 1021

committee_name: Support Our First Responders Now! Yes On N
candidate_or_measure: First Responder Student Loan And Training Reimbursement Fund
details: Prop. N would create a fund to repay first responders’ student loans. This would affect workers including sworn police officers, dispatchers, registered nurses and firefighters who would get up to $25,000 of their training costs reimbursed.
description: First responder student loan and training reimbursement fund
title: First responder student loan
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Dean Preston, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani

name: SF Forward
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.
title: Business tax reform
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.
proponents: San Francisco Chamber of Commerce; Mayor London Breed; Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Rafael Mandelman, Catherine Stefani, Ahsha Safaí, Myrna Melgar and Connie Chan
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: SF Forward Sponsored By San Francisco Chamber Of Commerce
committee_name: Committee To Fix San Francisco Government, Yes On D, No On E, A Coalition Of San Francisco Civic Organizations Dedicated To Improving The City'S Future
details: Prop. E would require the budget and legislative analyst to report on the fiscal impact of the city’s 130 commissions, and it would create a task force to determine how to change, eliminate or consolidate these commissions. It does not give more power to the mayor or the police chief.

sponsor: Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Connie Chan, Rafael Mandelman, Dean Preston, Hilary Ronen, Ahsha Safaí and Shamann Walton

name: Silvia Vasquez Lavado
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Susan Celia Swan
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.

name: Timothy Dilley
committee_name: Mayor Mark Farrell For Yes On Prop D
details: Prop. D would amend the city charter to limit the city to 65 commissions, which are civilian oversight or advisory bodies for city departments. The city currently has around 130 commissions. Prop. D would also give the mayor more power to appoint commissioners and to hire and fire department heads.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action

opponents: Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, ACLU of Northern California, Harvey Milk LGBT Democratic Club, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council

name: Timothy Mathews
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.
title: Ride-hailing vehicle tax
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures gathered by over 100 volunteers
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. M: It must receive more votes than Prop. M to go into effect.
proponents: State Sen. Scott Wiener; San Francisco Transit Riders; Supervisors Myrna Melgar, Connie Chan, Dean Preston, Joel Engardio, Hilary Ronen and Ahsha Safaí; Small Business Forward
opponents: Uber, Lyft, GrowSF, TogetherSF Action, SF Chamber of Commerce, California Nightlife Association

name: Tmg Partners
committee_name: Yes On F, San Franciscans For A Full Police Staffing
details: Prop. F would create a deferred retirement program for the police department. This would allow some officers, sergeants and inspectors to delay their retirement to do neighborhood patrols or investigative work. The measure would also change how the department reports staffing levels.
title: Police staffing
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar, Aaron Peskin, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: San Francisco Police Officers Association, Ripple executive chairman Chris Larsen, San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, Police Chief William Scott, Mayor London Breed
opponents: ACLU of Northern California; Supervisors Hilary Ronen, Dean Preston and Shamann Walton; Public Defender Mano Raju

name: Tmg Partners
committee_name: Healthy, Vibrant Sf, Yes On B
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Todco(John Elberling)
committee_name: Yes On G, The Affordable Housing Opportunity Fund
candidate_or_measure: Funding Rental Subsidies For Affordable Housing Developments Serving Low Income Seniors, Families, And Persons With Disabilities
details: Prop. G is a charter amendment creating an affordable housing fund to subsidize some extremely low-income rentals. The city would be required to allocate at least $8.25 million a year to that fund and the mayor’s office of housing and community development would disburse that money to the owners of certain affordable housing complexes.
title: Rental subsidies
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, San Francisco Tenants Union, Mercy Housing, Mission Economic Development Agency, Affordable Housing Alliance, Latino Task Force
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso, TogetherSF Action

name: Togethersf Action
committee_name: Committee To Fix San Francisco Government, Yes On D, No On E, A Coalition Of San Francisco Civic Organizations Dedicated To Improving The City'S Future
details: Prop. E would require the budget and legislative analyst to report on the fiscal impact of the city’s 130 commissions, and it would create a task force to determine how to change, eliminate or consolidate these commissions. It does not give more power to the mayor or the police chief.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Connie Chan, Rafael Mandelman, Dean Preston, Hilary Ronen, Ahsha Safaí and Shamann Walton
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. D: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.
proponents: ACLU of Northern California, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council
opponents: TogetherSF Action, Michael Moritz, Mark Farrell, Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, billionaire hedge fund investor William Oberndorf

name: Trinity Management Services
committee_name: San Franciscans For Responsible Housing, No On Proposition B, Sponsored By Rental Housing Providers
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

description: Close the Great Highway to cars
title: Close the Great Highway
sponsor: Supervisors Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar and Dean Preston

title: School improvement bond
sponsor: San Francisco Board of Education
required: Requires 55% affirmative votes.
proponents: SF Parent Action, SF Building and Construction Trades Council

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Committee To Fix San Francisco Government, Yes On D, No On E, A Coalition Of San Francisco Civic Organizations Dedicated To Improving The City'S Future
details: Prop. E would require the budget and legislative analyst to report on the fiscal impact of the city’s 130 commissions, and it would create a task force to determine how to change, eliminate or consolidate these commissions. It does not give more power to the mayor or the police chief.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Connie Chan, Rafael Mandelman, Dean Preston, Hilary Ronen, Ahsha Safaí and Shamann Walton
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. D: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.
proponents: ACLU of Northern California, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council
opponents: TogetherSF Action, Michael Moritz, Mark Farrell, Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, billionaire hedge fund investor William Oberndorf

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Committee To Fix San Francisco Government, Yes On D, No On E, A Coalition Of San Francisco Civic Organizations Dedicated To Improving The City'S Future
details: Prop. D would amend the city charter to limit the city to 65 commissions, which are civilian oversight or advisory bodies for city departments. The city currently has around 130 commissions. Prop. D would also give the mayor more power to appoint commissioners and to hire and fire department heads.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. E: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.
proponents: TogetherSF Action, Michael Moritz, Mark Farrell, Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, billionaire hedge fund investor William Oberndorf
opponents: Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, ACLU of Northern California, Harvey Milk LGBT Democratic Club, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Support Our First Responders Now! Yes On N
candidate_or_measure: First Responder Student Loan And Training Reimbursement Fund
details: Prop. N would create a fund to repay first responders’ student loans. This would affect workers including sworn police officers, dispatchers, registered nurses and firefighters who would get up to $25,000 of their training costs reimbursed.
description: First responder student loan and training reimbursement fund
title: First responder student loan
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Dean Preston, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani

opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Yes On B, Committee To Restore Police Minimum Staffing And Public Safety, Sponsored By Labor Organizations
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Yes On H For Firefighters Health & Safety, Sf Fire Fighters Local 798
details: Prop. H would allow all firefighters to receive their maximum pension at 55 instead of 58. Currently, only firefighters hired before 2012 can obtain their maximum pension at 55.
title: Firefighter measure
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: San Francisco Fire Fighters Local 798
opponents: Libertarian Party of San Francisco

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.

sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.

committee_name: Yes On G, The Affordable Housing Opportunity Fund
candidate_or_measure: Funding Rental Subsidies For Affordable Housing Developments Serving Low Income Seniors, Families, And Persons With Disabilities
details: Prop. G is a charter amendment creating an affordable housing fund to subsidize some extremely low-income rentals. name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.
title: Business tax reform
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.
proponents: San Francisco Chamber of Commerce; Mayor London Breed; Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Rafael Mandelman, Catherine Stefani, Ahsha Safaí, Myrna Melgar and Connie Chan
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Unitemized Schedule A
committee_name: Yes On F, San Franciscans For A Full Police Staffing
details: Prop. F would create a deferred retirement program for the police department. This would allow some officers, sergeants and inspectors to delay their retirement to do neighborhood patrols or investigative work. The measure would also change how the department reports staffing levels.
title: Police staffing
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar, Aaron Peskin, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: San Francisco Police Officers Association, Ripple executive chairman Chris Larsen, San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, Police Chief William Scott, Mayor London Breed
opponents: ACLU of Northern California; Supervisors Hilary Ronen, Dean Preston and Shamann Walton; Public Defender Mano Raju

candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.

sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Real Reform, Yes On C, No On D, Yes On E, A Coalition Of Small Businesses, Neighbors And Aaron Peskin
details: Prop. C would create an inspector general for San Francisco to investigate claims of fraud, waste and abuse. The inspector would have the power of subpoena and the power to issue search warrants.
title: Inspector general
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Former City Controller Ed Harrington, Assemblymember Phil Ting, former Mayor Art Agnos, former state Sen. Mark Leno, San Francisco Tenants Union
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Real Reform, Yes On C, No On D, Yes On E, A Coalition Of Small Businesses, Neighbors And Aaron Peskin
details: Prop. E would require the budget and legislative analyst to report on the fiscal impact of the city’s 130 commissions, and it would create a task force to determine how to change, eliminate or consolidate these commissions. It does not give more power to the mayor or the police chief.

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Great Schools For All Sf Kids - Yes On Prop A
details: Prop. A would authorize the San Francisco Unified School District to borrow up to $790 million to be repaid through property taxes. The money could be used for health and safety upgrades, such as heating and plumbing, and technology infrastructure.
title: School improvement bond
sponsor: San Francisco Board of Education
required: Requires 55% affirmative votes.
proponents: SF Parent Action, SF Building and Construction Trades Council
opponents: Libertarian Party of San Francisco, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.
title: Ride-hailing vehicle tax
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures gathered by over 100 volunteers
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. M: It must receive more votes than Prop. M to go into effect.

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Support Our First Responders Now! Yes On N
candidate_or_measure: First Responder Student Loan And Training Reimbursement Fund
details: Prop. N would create a fund to repay first responders’ student loans. This would affect workers including sworn police officers, dispatchers, registered nurses and firefighters who would get up to $25,000 of their training costs reimbursed.
description: First responder student loan and training reimbursement fund
title: First responder student loan
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Dean Preston, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Service Employees International Union Local 1021, San Francisco Police Officers Association, San Francisco Deputy Sheriffs’ Association, Firefighters Local 798
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Yes On B, Committee To Restore Police Minimum Staffing And Public Safety, Sponsored By Labor Organizations
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Yes On H For Firefighters Health & Safety, Sf Fire Fighters Local 798
details: Prop. H would allow all firefighters to receive their maximum pension at 55 instead of 58. Currently, only firefighters hired before 2012 can obtain their maximum pension at 55.
title: Firefighter measure
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: San Francisco Fire Fighters Local 798
opponents: Libertarian Party of San Francisco

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.

sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.

details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Committee To Fix San Francisco Government, Yes On D, No On E, A Coalition Of San Francisco Civic Organizations Dedicated To Improving The City'S Future
details: Prop. D would amend the city charter to limit the city to 65 commissions, which are civilian oversight or advisory bodies for city departments. The city currently has around 130 commissions. Prop. D would also give the mayor more power to appoint commissioners and to hire and fire department heads.
title: Commission reform
sponsor: Received over 50,012 signatures gathered by TogetherSF Action
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. E: If both pass, the one which gets the most votes will be enacted.
proponents: TogetherSF Action, Michael Moritz, Mark Farrell, Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, billionaire hedge fund investor William Oberndorf
opponents: Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, ACLU of Northern California, Harvey Milk LGBT Democratic Club, San Francisco Tenants Union, San Francisco Labor Council

name: Unitemized Schedule C
committee_name: Revitalize San Francisco, Yes On M
details: Prop. M would change the city’s business tax structure. It would shift the structure away from payroll taxes to gross receipts taxes. This would shift some burden off the biggest companies, but also from the smallest ones.
title: Business tax reform
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. Prop. M would nullify Prop. L if it receives more votes. If they both pass and Prop. L receives more votes, both will be enacted.
proponents: San Francisco Chamber of Commerce; Mayor London Breed; Supervisors Aaron Peskin, Rafael Mandelman, Catherine Stefani, Ahsha Safaí, Myrna Melgar and Connie Chan
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: William Russell-Shapiro
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Yensing Sihapanya
committee_name: Yes On L, Fund The Bus
candidate_or_measure: Additional Business Tax On Transportation Network Companies And Autonomous Vehicle Businesses To Fund Public Transportation
details: Prop. L would tax ride-hailing and self-driving car companies. The revenue would go to maintaining or growing Muni services, such as increasing service frequency or expanding free fare programs.
title: Ride-hailing vehicle tax
sponsor: Received over 10,029 signatures gathered by over 100 volunteers
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes. This measure competes with Prop. M: It must receive more votes than Prop. M to go into effect.
proponents: State Sen. Scott Wiener; San Francisco Transit Riders; Supervisors Myrna Melgar, Connie Chan, Dean Preston, Joel Engardio, Hilary Ronen and Ahsha Safaí; Small Business Forward
opponents: Uber, Lyft, GrowSF, TogetherSF Action, SF Chamber of Commerce, California Nightlife Association

name: Yes On B, Committee To Restore Police Minimum Staffing And Public Safety, Sponsored By Labor Organizations
committee_name: Support Our First Responders Now! Yes On N
candidate_or_measure: First Responder Student Loan And Training Reimbursement Fund
details: Prop. N would create a fund to repay first responders’ student loans. This would affect workers including sworn police officers, dispatchers, registered nurses and firefighters who would get up to $25,000 of their training costs reimbursed.
description: First responder student loan and training reimbursement fund
title: First responder student loan
sponsor: Supervisors Connie Chan, Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Dean Preston, Ahsha Safaí and Catherine Stefani
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: Service Employees International Union Local 1021, San Francisco Police Officers Association, San Francisco Deputy Sheriffs’ Association, Firefighters Local 798
opponents: Republican tech executive Larry Marso

name: Yes On Prop E For A Safer SF - Mayor Breed'S Ballot Measure Committee
committee_name: Mayor Breed'S Committee For Reproductive Freedom, Yes On O
details: Prop. O is a local response to national threats to reproductive healthcare access. Part of it is a declaration that San Francisco protects the rights of people seeking reproductive care. It would also make some substantive changes such as creating a fund that accepts grants and gifts to pay and tweak zoning rules to expand the areas where reproductive clinics can operate.
title: Supporting Reproductive Freedom
sponsor: Mayor London Breed
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: The Board of Supervisors, state Sen. Scott Wiener
opponents: Pro-Life San Francisco Executive Director Melanie Salazar

name: Yusheng Dent
committee_name: Healthy, Vibrant Sf, Yes On B
candidate_or_measure: Community Health And Medical Facilities, Street Safety, Public Spaces, And Shelter To Reduce Homelessness Bond
details: Prop. B is a bond for infrastructure upgrade projects around the city. It would authorize the city to borrow $390 million in general obligation bonds for repairs and improvements to community, housing and hospital infrastructure. The bond would be paid back with property taxes.
title: Community health and medical facilities
sponsor: The Board of Supervisors (unanimous)
required: Requires 66.67% affirmative votes. However, this measure will require 55% to pass if voters also approve state Proposition 5.
proponents: Mayor London Breed, state Sen. Scott Wiener, California State Controller Malia Cohen, CEO at Zuckerberg General Hospital CEO Susan Ehrlich
opponents: The Briones Society of the San Francisco Republican Party, San Francisco Apartment Association

name: Yvonne Robertson
committee_name: Great Highway For All - No On K, A Matt Boschetto Committee
candidate_or_measure: Permanently Closing The Upper Great Highway To Private Vehicles To Establish A Public Open Recreation Space
details: Prop. K would permanently close part of the Great Highway (between Lincoln and Sloat) to cars, in preparation for turning it into a park.
description: Close the Great Highway to cars
title: Close the Great Highway
sponsor: Supervisors Matt Dorsey, Joel Engardio, Rafael Mandelman, Myrna Melgar and Dean Preston
required: Requires 50%+1 affirmative votes.
proponents: State Sen. Scott Wiener, Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi, Outer Sunset Neighbors, SF Surfers for Ocean Beach Park, Yelp CEO Jeremy Stoppelman, Sierra Club, Y Combinator pPartner Emmett Shear, SPUR, San Francisco Parks Alliance
opponents: Coalition for San Francisco Neighborhoods, Neighborhoods United SF, District 7 supervisor candidate Matt Boschetto
